title: 107_hr1098
content: The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" is the short title of this Act. The table of contents for this Act is provided in Section 2. The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" is also known as the "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001". The Act includes various provisions related to vessels, maritime liens, certificates of documentation, exemptions, and waivers for specific vessels. SEC. 3. VESSEL COASTAL VENTURE. Amends Section 1120(g) of the Coast Guard Authorization Act of 1996 by adding a specific vessel, COASTAL VENTURE (United States official number 971086). SEC. 4. EXPANSION OF AMERICAN MERCHANT MARINE MEMORIAL WALL OF HONOR. The Congress recognizes the historical significance of the United States Merchant Marine in serving the nation during wars since 1775, including its crucial role in gaining independence and supporting allies in World War II. President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the military played key roles in these efforts. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine played a significant role in the victory of the allies, with over 250,000 men and women serving and facing dangers from the elements. President Franklin D. Roosevelt and military leaders praised the Merchant Marine as the "Fourth Arm of Defense." During World War II, more than 250,000 men and women served in the United States Merchant Marine, facing dangers from submarines, mines, armed raiders, destroyers, aircraft, and kamikaze pilots. At least 6,830 members were killed at sea, and 11,000 were wounded, with 1,100 later dying from their wounds. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine faced significant dangers, with 6,830 members killed at sea, 11,000 wounded, and 604 taken prisoner. 1 in 32 members died in the line of duty, a higher percentage than any other armed service in the US. The Merchant Marine continues to serve. The United States Merchant Marine suffered a high percentage of war-related deaths during World War II, with 6,830 members killed at sea. The Merchant Marine continues to serve the US and promote freedom. The Secretary of Transportation may provide grants for constructing an addition to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor. The Secretary of Transportation may provide grants to the American Merchant Marine Veterans Memorial Committee, Inc., to construct an addition to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor in California. The Federal share of the cost will be 50 percent, with an authorization of $500,000 for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 5. DISCHARGE OF AGRICULTURAL CARGO RESIDUE. The discharge of agricultural cargo residue material from a vessel shall be governed by the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships. SEC. 6. RECORDING AND DISCHARGING MARITIME LIENS. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels under chapter 121. The Secretary is required to record a notice complying with the regulations. The application for documentation under chapter 121 requires the Secretary to record a notice if a declaration is filed with the notice stating the information is true and correct. The notice for vessel documentation must be true and correct, and copies must be sent to the owner, holders of liens, and mortgagees. The notice for vessel documentation must be accurate and copies must be provided to the owner, lien holders, and mortgagees. Declarations filed by non-individuals must be signed by authorized officials. Upon full discharge of the debt, a notice of lien can be removed. Upon full discharge of the debt, a person must provide an acknowledged certificate of discharge to the Secretary, who will record it. District courts have jurisdiction over civil actions to declare a vessel not subject to a lien or notice of claim of lien. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction over civil actions to declare a vessel not subject to a lien or notice of claim of lien, regardless of the amount in controversy or the parties' citizenship. Venue for such actions can be where the vessel is found, where the claimant resides, or where the notice of claim of lien is recorded. The court may award costs and attorneys fees to the prevailing party, unless justified otherwise. A notice of claim of lien recorded under subsection (b) of this section shall expire 3 years after the date specified in the notice. This section does not affect the law regarding maritime liens, remedies, or defenses, including the defense of laches. The notice of claim of lien recorded under subsection (b) expires after 3 years. This section does not change the law on maritime liens, remedies, or defenses, including the defense of laches. Section 31343 amends notice requirements for recording and discharging liens in title 46 of the United States Code. It specifies that an unexpired notice of a claim must be used. Additionally, section 12111 is amended to prevent the Secretary from refusing to approve the surrender of documentation for a vessel based solely on this issue. The Secretary cannot reject the surrender of a vessel's documentation due to a lien claim notice. Approval may be subject to conditions for vessels over 1,000 gross tons. The Shipping Act, 1916 is amended regarding vessel documentation for vessels over 1,000 gross tons. The amendment will take effect on July 1, 2002. SEC. 7. Tonnage of R/V DAVIDSON: The Secretary of Transportation will determine the tonnage measurement for the vessel R/V DAVIDSON as a small passenger vessel for regulatory purposes. This applies when the vessel complies with specific requirements. SEC. 8. Miscellaneous Certificates of Documentation. The Secretary of Transportation may issue a certificate of documentation for employment in the coastwise trade for specific vessels, including LOOKING GLASS, YANKEE, LUCKY DOG, and ENTERPRIZE. The vessels listed for certification include YANKEE, LUCKY DOG, ENTERPRIZE, M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, and SKIMMER. The vessels listed for certification are VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, SKIMMER, TOKEENA, DOUBLE EAGLE2, ENCOUNTER, AJ, and BARGE 10. The vessels listed for certification are DOUBLE EAGLE2, ENCOUNTER, AJ, BARGE 10, NOT A SHOT, PRIDE OF MANY, AMAZING GRACE, and SHEWHO. SEC. 9. EXEMPTION FOR VICTORY SHIPS. Amends Section 3302(l)(1) of title 46, United States Code to exempt the steamship SS Red Oak Victory and the SS American Victory. SEC. 10. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR 3 BARGES. The Secretary of Transportation may issue a certificate of documentation for employment in the coastwise trade for specific vessels, including the former Navy deck barge JIM and the former railroad car barge HUGH. The former Navy deck barge JIM, the former railroad car barge HUGH, and the former railroad car barge TOMMY have specific dimensions. Vessels issued a certificate of documentation under this section are limited to being used as floating platforms for launching fireworks. SEC. 11. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR THE EAGLE. The Secretary of Transportation will issue a certificate of documentation for the vessel EAGLE for coastwise trade if owned or chartered by a State entity. The vessel must be owned or chartered by a State entity, operated in conjunction with scour jet operations or dredging services, and clearly identified as belonging to that State, subdivision, or authority. SEC. 12. WAIVER FOR VESSELS IN NEW WORLD CHALLENGE RACE. Sailboats in the New World Challenge Race can transport guests without payment from San Francisco and San Diego ports until race completion or December 31, 2003. SEC. 13. VESSEL ASPHALT COMMANDER may be transferred to a foreign registry or sold to a non-US citizen.
